SPX +0.34% at 2794, NDX +0.04% at 7760, DJI +0.57% at 24917.

Despite thin volumes, the familiar theme of flattening was again seen on Tuesday; 2s30s and 5s30s printed fresh narrows not seen in a decade, while 2s10s narrowed further, and was beneath 28bps at settlement. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 3+ ticks lower at 120-00+.

US MARKET WRAP - 10 July 2018: Thin markets allow mild risk rally to continue
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, crude up, dollar up.
* REAR-VIEW: JOLTS slip, but quit rate at cycle high; more Brexit resignations; EIA cuts 2018 world demand growth view; earnings season underway, PEP beats on top and bottom-lines; very soft 3s auction.
* COMING-UP: BOC rate decision; ECB’s Draghi, Praet, Mersch, Villeroy; BOE’s Carney; Fed’s Williams; NATO summit.

* JOLTS: Job openings slipped by 200k in May to 6.6 million, which analysts at Wells Fargo said is still consistent with an extremely tight labour market. Analysts also noted that the quits rate rose to a new cyclical high at 2.4%, which may augur well for future wage growth. Meanwhile, the ratio between unemployed workers to job openings remained at the record low 0.9, lending to evidence of labour market tightness.

* FED DISCOUNT RATE MINUTES: Fed directors reported solid economic activity; some regional Fed directors were concerned by trade risks. Eleven regional banks sought a hike to the discount rate (all but the NY Fed voted for a hike).

* * SPX +0.34% at 2794, NDX +0.04% at 7760, DJI +0.57% at 24917. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +1.26%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.22%, Energy: +0.73%, Financials: -0.37%, Health Care: +0.41%, Industrials: +0.34%, Materials: +0.84%, Telecoms: +1.13%, Tech: +0.23%, Utilities: +0.97%.

* FUTURES: ES futures ultimately traversed horizontally, with most of the gains coming in overnight trade, where the Emini ticked up around 5 points to 2790, a level which it continued to straddle through European/North American trade (we did get into spitting distance of 2800 but stopped a couple of points short). Wires have tried to spin the equity price action by pointing to oil price gains, trade fears being on the bac-burner, and expectations of a decent earnings season; but in truth, action was subdued, and volumes were thin.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: PepsiCo (PEP) kicked off earnings season with a top- and bottom-line beat; numbers were helped by its foods business, but it noted a loss of share in the cola marker, weighing on the beverage unit. Tesla (TSLA) was buoyed on news it plans to open a factory in China which will manufacture 500k vehicles annually. Microsoft (MSFT) was slightly higher after it slashed prices for Surface tablets, and introduced a new model with a $399 price point in order to compete with Apple (APPL). Elsewhere in tech, Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) Google facing a multi-billion euro fine by EU antitrust regulators. In broker moves, Micron (MU) was positively mentioned in a JPMorgan note. Wynn (WYNN) resorts was upgraded at Stifel. On the other side, Chipotle (CMG) was hit after a downgrade at Mizuho, eBay (EBAY) was downgraded at SunTrust, Nordstrom (JWN) downgraded at Keybanc, and Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) was downgraded at Evercore ISI.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLES 3+ TICKS LOWER AT 120-00+. Despite thin volumes, the familiar theme of flattening was again seen on Tuesday; 2s30s and 5s30s printed fresh narrows not seen in a decade, while 2s10s narrowed further, and was beneath 28bps at settlement.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION REVIEW: The week’s US supply got off to a very soft start, with the US selling $33bln at a high yield of 2.685% (highest stop-out rate since May 2007), tailing by 0.6bps (biggest tail since September 2017); cover, meanwhile was the weakest at a 3s auctions since April 2009. The internals were grim: direct bidders took the smallest share since December 2017, indirect bidders took the smallest since November 2014, leaving primary dealers with a huge 51.3%, the most since June 2014. The weak auction saw yields tick-up slightly in its wake.  

* 10-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The Treasury will this week auction USD 69bln in new supply (USD 33bln of 3-year notes on Tuesday, USD 22bln 10-year reopening on Wednesday, USD 14bln of reopened 30-year bonds on Thursday). USD 28.7bln in new cash will be raised, given the USD 40.3bln maturing mid-month, according to TD Securities. Last month’s 10s auction saw the highest cover since January, though the stop-out rate was the lowest since April. Dealer positioning suggests that dealers are net long to the tune of USD 3.82bln in the 7-11 year sector, also the lowest since April. Analysts at Societe Generale say the current 10s appear slightly cheap on the curve versus old 10s relative to the previous two auction cycles, and continues to trade near the cheapest level in years versus the 5s and 30s, though it has richened from May. SocGen notes, however, that 2s10s continues to flatten, and at 29bps, the spread is close to decade lows. Nevertheless, SocGen says the cheapness of the sector from a relative value perspective is a positive, but believes some concession may be required given benchmark 10-year yields are below the last two stop-out rates.

* WTI (Q8) SETTLES 26C HIGHER AT $74.11/BBL; BRENT (U8) SETTLES 79C HIGHER AT $78.86/BBL. Crude extended gains ahead of weekly inventory US data, which is expected to show headline crude draw of 4.2mln, distillates are expected to build by 1.3mln, and gasoline stocks are seen drawing down by 900k. Brent was gaining support by the oil workers strike in Norway. There was also another round of belligerent talk from Iran, with the vice president saying Iran will sell as much oil as it can despite the US sanctions, adding that Iran will do everything so that America realises that they will not be able to stop Iranian oil exports. Meanwhile, US officials have reportedly held discussions in Saudi Arabia to help partners find alternatives to Iranian oil, and officials also discussed maintaining a well-stocked oil market to guard against volatility. In other geopolitics, the Houthis continue to attempt to fire missiles at the Saudi Jazan facility, though the Saudis intercepted the latest efforts. There were some negative ticks in the afternoon, after the EIA released its latest STEO, where it cut its forecast for 2018 world oil demand growth by 80k BPD, now sees 1.72mln BPD Y/Y rise; cuts forecast for 2019 world oil demand growth by 10k BPD, now sees a 1.71mln BPD Y/Y rise, and it left its estimate for US output unchanged at 10.79mln BPD.

* FOREX: It is hard to read too much into FX moves given that news flow has been quiet, and there has also been a quiet feel to markets on Tuesday. The general theme seems to be mild risk-on, with safe havens slipping (JPY down 0.35% versus the EUR and USD; CHF down by 0.1% vs the USD and the EUR; XAU is slightly negative, though did slip below $1250 briefly, before recovering). The EUR was being hampered by a weak German ZEW survey, which missed expectations. But the overall risk backdrop was constructive, which helped carry (AUDJPY up 0.45% despite trading flat against the buck, NZDUSD +0.45%, again despite the NZD being flat against the USD), and EMFX (BRL gains nearly 2% against the buck, ZAR around 1%, and even the TRY managed to carve out 0.6% gains against the dollar – the new Turkish finance chief said budget and fiscal discipline will be sustained more actively). Commodity FX was flat against the dollar, despite crude trading higher; the CAD is treading water ahead of tomorrow’s BOC rates decision, where it is expected to lift rates.

* GBP: Sterling, meanwhile, has stabilised after Monday’s choppy session, with cable holding around 1.3260, while EURGBP slipped to as low as 0.8820 at one point, before making its way back towards 0.8850. There was some positive ticks on news that the two Tory Party vice chairs are the latest to quit their roles due to the government’s handling of Brexit, and according to the Sun, more resignations are expected. Attention is on Thursday’s release of the long-awaited white paper, which is expected to show a notable softening in the UK’s negotiating position;

* COMING-UP: BOC RATE DECISION. The Bank of Canada is likely to resume tightening policy and is seen hiking interest rates by 25bps to 1.50% on Wednesday. Of the 25 analysts surveyed by Reuters, 20 expect the BoC to hike with just 5 expecting no change at the meeting. Markets are currently pricing in over 95% chance for a rate hike at this meeting. The Monetary Policy Report is also due to be released at this meeting and there will be press conference from Governor Poloz and Deputy Governor Wilkins following the meeting at 1615BST/1115EDT. Read the full RANsquawk preview here.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar proffers at the expense of others
content:
DXY

The index has extended recovery gains above the 94.000 handle, topping out just shy of 94.500 as major and some EM counterparts pare losses and/or stage rebounds from recent lows.

GBP

The Pound is ending Tuesday’s session ahead of the G10 pack and well off lows registered in the wake of unexpectedly soft UK data (especially ip that fell vs consensus for a 0.5% rise and together with sub-forecast manufacturing output more than offset in line ONS monthly GDP readings). Relatively firm growth estimates from the NIESR for Q2 and Q3 may have given Sterling a boost, while PM May surviving to fight another day after the post-Chequers fall-out certainly provided some respite ahead of the aforementioned data-fest. Cable is currently around 1.3270 within 1.3300-1.3225 parameters and Eur/Gbp under 0.8825 vs 0.8875 at one stage.

EUR/JPY    

Biggest losers vs the Greenback, with the single currency ruffled by disappointing ZEW expectations and current conditions, and then buffeted amidst more Italian Euro exit headlines (Savona saying Rome must prepare for all eventualities and it could hinge on other members whether it stays or goes). Eur/Usd has recovered 1.1700+ status with decent bids said to be layered below the big figure and several MAs. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy has broken out of recent ranges and cleared multi-top resistance above 111.00 to reach 111.35 and the base of a 111.22-59 technical area that includes a major trend-line and decent offers between 111.40-50, according to market observers.

CHF/CAD    

The next weakest major links, with the Franc losing out amidst broadly upbeat risk sentiment, like its Jpy safe-haven peer and down towards 0.9950 vs the Usd, while the Loonie failed to derive any real benefit from strong Canadian housing data in the form of starts and permits amidst some squaring and consolidation ahead of tomorrow’s BoC policy meeting. Usd/Cad held within a 1.3100-45 range as a 25 bp hike is almost unanimously anticipated and priced – full preview to be posted shortly via our headline feed and available on the research suite.

AUD/NZD

Pretty even-steven down under as the antipodean dollars both fell from recent peaks vs their US peer to around 0.7450 and 0.6825 respectively.

TRY/NOK

Volatile trade for the Lira that slumped on President Erdogan’s appointment of a new Treasury and Finance Minister to replace investor favourites previously holding each role, but the Try paring losses when the former (who is also a family member by marriage) pledged to follow strict budget and economic policies – Usd/Try now just below 4.7000 vs 4.7500+ at one stage. Conversely, then Nok tested bids vs the Eur under 9.3900 after firm headline Norwegian CPI before losing momentum on the benign core indices.

subject: Daily US Equity Opening News 10 July 2018: PepsiCo (PEP) beats, Microsoft (MSFT) introduces new tablet, eBay (EBAY) downgraded at SunTrust, WBA downgraded at Evercore
content:
9th July 2018

EARNINGS

  • PepsiCo (PEP) – The beverage and snack manufacturer reports Q2 EPS of 1.61 (USD), beating the consensus 1.52; revenue was 16.09bln, slightly beating the 16.04bln expectation. Co. says remains on track to achieve its financial targets. Analysts noted that earnings were buoyed by its food operations, and said that the loss of market share in its cola division is hurting its beverage unit. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Microsoft (MSFT) – Tech giant is cutting prices on its Surface devices in order to compete with Apple’s (AAPL) iPad, and has introduced a new tablet with a USD 399 price point. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Allergan (AGN) – The pharma company launches a new over-the-counter artificial tear formulation eye drops. (Newswires)
  • Aptiv (APTV) – Auto parts company will acquire Winchester Interconnect for USD 650mln, subject to regulatory approval; APTV intends to operate Winchester Interconnect as an independent entity within its Signal & Power Solutions division. (Newswires)
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) – The energy company has requested a NY Federal Court take control of legal claims brought by Venezuela’s state oil company PDVSA against foreign oil traders, after accusing it of bringing claims against subsidiaries in an effort to evade a USD 2bln award to COP. (Newswires)
  • Celgene (CELG) – Drug makers Celgene and Acceleron (XLRN) announce positive results from a phase 3 study for Luspatercept. (Newswires)
  • J.M. Smucker (SJM) – The packaged foods company set to divest its US baking business for USD 375mln. (Newsiwres)
  • Lowe’s (LOW) – Home improvement retailer has eliminated the roles of chief operating officer, chief customer officer, corporate administration executive, and chief development officer which some analysts say will improve execution. (Newswires)
  • Micron Technology (MU) – JPMorgan analyst says higher server DRAM outlook is a positive for semiconductor company. (Newswires)
  • Nordstrom (JWN) – The retailer announced it will no longer open two additional ‘Nordstrom Local Shops’ in LA this autumn. (Newswires)
  • Paccar (PCAR) – The truck manufacturer announced a USD 300mln share buyback programme after recently completing its previous USD 300mln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Under Armour (UA, UAA) – The sports company is well-positioned to meet or beat on its Q2 guidance, Barclays’ analysts said in a note. (Newswires)
  • Xerox (XRX) – Fuji Xerox CEO said the joint venture between Xerox and Fujifilm will not be broken up despite the dispute between the two which saw the planned merger cancelled by Xerox. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) – The tech giant has committed USD 25mln to YouTube to improve its news features and how it handles breaking news, which will help highlight breaking news videos from external news organisations. (Newswires)
  • Amazon.com (AMZN) – Amazon announce exclusive ways Prime Members will be able to save in Whole Food Markets stores in celebration of its Prime Day (a day and a half) on 16 July. (Newswires)
  • Baidu (BIDU) – Co. to collaborate with BMW to develop autonomous vehicles in China. Co. has also signed an MOU with Hyundai Motor for “Internet of Vehicles”. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Surprise UK Industrial Output miss reverses GBP early rise, German ZEW conditions miss hits EUR
  • European equities largely higher following in step with Asia in a news-thin morning
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, APIs and ECB’s Lautenschlaeger

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher on the momentum from Wall St where the DJIA notched its best performance in a month, and financials outperformed on optimism heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) initially took impetus from US and both opened higher although the Australia index later pared gains amid losses in its largest weighted financials sector, while Tokyo stocks remained firm on a weaker currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) conformed to the overall positive tone. The Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was choppy but ended positive despite continued inaction by the PBoC resulted to a CNY 30bln liquidity drain, while participants also digested CPI and PPI figures which either printed inline or firmer than expected. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with demand weighed by the overall positive risk appetite and after the 5yr auction failed to support prices despite showing stronger interest with both b/c and accepted prices firmer than prior.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 30bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6259 (Prev. 6.6393)

Chinese CPI (Jun) Y/Y 1.90% vs. Exp. 1.90% (Prev. 1.80%). (Newswires)

Chinese PPI (Jun) Y/Y 4.70% vs. Exp. 4.50% (Prev. 4.10%)

China Mofcom announced measures to mitigate impact of trade dispute with US, in which new tax income from countermeasures against US will mainly be utilized to ease impact to companies and workers. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK Monthly GDP Estimate YY (May) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.40%

UK Monthly GDP Estimate MM (May) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.30%

UK Manufacturing Output MM (May) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.70% (Prev. -1.40%, Rev. -1.3%)

UK Manufacturing Output YY (May) 1.1% vs. Exp. 2.00% (Prev. 1.40%, Rev. 0.9%)

UK Industrial Output YY (May) 0.8% vs. Exp. 1.90% (Prev. 1.80%, Rev. 1.6%)

UK Industrial Output MM (May) -0.4% vs. Exp. 0.50% (Prev. -0.80%, Rev. -1.0%)

German ZEW Current Conditions (Jul) 72.4 vs. Exp. 78.2 (Prev. 80.6)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Jul) -24.7 vs. Exp. -18.2 (Prev. -16.1)

San Francisco Fed economic letter noted economic upside from tax cuts may not meet analysts' overly optimistic expectations. (Newswires)

US President Trump nominated judge Brett Kavanaugh for US Supreme Court Justice. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are largely positive (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%), with the IBEX (-0.1%) currently the underperforming bourse, pressured by losses in BBVA (-2.5%), whom are being hit by falling Turkish fixed income prices in the wake of Erdogan’s seating, as a result of their exposure to this market.

The CAC (+0.3%) is outperforming bourse, led by index heavyweight Airbus (+2.3%) on the back of a positive note by Bank of America.

TP ICAP (-32.2%) shares are crashing after they announced their CEO is to leave his post, and reduced their synergy targets.

21st Century Fox (FOXA) is preparing a new bid for Sky (SKY LN) (+2.2%) that would value it at GBP 25bln, and top the offer made by Comcast (CMCSA), as according to sources.

PepsiCo Inc (PEP) Q2 EPS USD 1.61 vs. Exp. USD 1.51, revenue USD 16.1bln vs. Exp. USD 16.05bln

FIXED INCOME

In the end it seems that good old fashioned economic indicators overshadowed new ONS releases, as big UK ip and manufacturing output misses helped Gilts bounce off worst levels to 122.95 vs 122.84 at one stage (-31 ticks). Bunds have also regained some composure off a fresh 162.26 Eurex base (-35 ticks) amidst reports of supply hedging via 10 year swaps ahead of tomorrow’s new German benchmark and as books build for long end syndications. Note, a considerably weaker than forecast ZEW survey has also prompted some short covering. Elsewhere, US Treasuries have slipped a fraction in thin overnight trade, and also have issuance to make room for alongside a relatively light data schedule.

FX

GBP - Some calm after Monday’s UK political storm for the Pound as PM May resisted growing pressure and heightened prospects of a no confidence vote after the resignations of Brexit Minister Davis and Foreign Minister Johnson. Cable rebounded pretty firmly from just under 1.3200 to retest 1.3300 in the run up to a raft of data, while Eur/Gbp pulled back from 0.8875 before Sterling sold off again on much weaker than forecast IP and manufacturing output readings that ultimately stole the limelight from much hyped new monthly ONS GDP figures that were broadly in line with consensus anyway. Cable back near 1.3250 and the cross just shy of 0.8850.

EUR - The single currency was also undermined by negative macro factors as the latest ZEW survey deteriorated much more than anticipated, albeit on heightened political uncertainty in July, some of which has dissipated, alongside rising concerns about global trade wars and in particular the tariff spat with the US. Eur/Usd has subsequently retreated from around 1.1760 to test layered bids ahead of 1.1700.

JPY/AUD/NZD - All around 0.3% lower vs the Greenback, as Jpy marginally breaks down through recent lows circa 111.00+ and is now eyeing bids said to be housed between 111.22-59 (a chart resistance zone), with option flow reportedly looking at upside strikes in the headline pair. The Aud is back below 0.7450 having failed to seriously test key resistance just ahead of 0.7500 and the Kiwi is back towards 0.6800 with the cross remaining above 1.0900.

CAD - Also softer vs the Usd with the pair over 1.3100, but the Loonie looking towards housing data later for independent impetus before a widely expected and priced BoC hike on Wednesday.

DXY - The index has reclaimed 94.000, largely by virtue of all the weakness in rival G10 currencies rather than anything Dollar supportive.

TRY - The Lira has been trashed again as fears about changes in key cabinet roles by President Erdogan were realised with the appointment of his son-in-law to the newly formed and combined office of Economy and Treasury Minister, replacing two tried and trusted people – Simsek and Agbal. Usd/Try has been up over 4.7500, but currently around 4.7000.

COMMODITIES

Oil is currently up on the day, with WTI +0.5% and Brent +0.8%. Some traders are eyeing developments in the Knarr oilfield in Norway with Shell confirming it is to stop production due to strike action. This comes as supply concerns remain in the middle east, with the UAE energy minister saying it is time for extra supply to come into the market and that OPEC has enough capacity to offset output shortfalls.

Most metals are softer this morning with Gold slightly down on a rising dollar, that is recovering from near 3 week lows. Silver, Copper, Platinum and Palladium are all also negative on a higher dollar, with steel the only metal bucking the trend on unconfirmed reports of Tangshan production to be cut by 50%.

subject: PepsiCo Inc (PEP) Q2 EPS USD 1.61 vs. Exp. USD 1.51, revenue USD 16.1bln vs. Exp. USD 16.05bln

UK debt and STIR futures: on the defensive ahead of data deluge
content: A fleeting uptick off a marginally firmer open for Gilts has quickly given way to downside price action within 122.90-123.20 Liffe parameters vs the previous 123.15 settlement, while the Short Sterling strip has also faded after nudging a tick above par to stand flat to 1 tick softer. The bearish tone is more in keeping with moves elsewhere, ie Bunds down to 162.36 (-1/4 point on the day), and also in advance of a packed domestic agenda with multiple releases at 9.30BST, including the new ONS monthly GDP series. Meanwhile, any safe-haven type demand appears less compelling as PM May looks to have escaped a vote of confidence, for the time being at least.

Bunds: straddling 162.50 line after another markdown
content: The pattern is becoming very familiar, but closing highs are gradually declining as core bonds drift down to the lower bounds of recent ranges ahead of this week’s hefty supply. The early Eurex range for 10 year German debt is 162.56-47 vs Monday’s 162.61 close, and the corresponding yield is around 0.31% as the curve steepens a little. Ahead, the latest ZEW survey may provide some additional impetus , especially as economic sentiment and current conditions are both forecast to moderate vs other surveys and data coming in above consensus or more stable. Turning to the near term technical outlook, market contacts note that a chart gap has been filled at 162.54 after the initial mark down to 162.49 and dip to 162.47, but intraday resistance resides up at 162.61 and yesterday’s session low was 162.35.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher on the momentum from Wall St where the DJIA notched its best performance in a month, and financials outperformed on optimism heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) initially took impetus from US and both opened higher although the Australia index later pared gains amid losses in its largest weighted financials sector, while Tokyo stocks remained firm on a weaker currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) conformed to the overall positive tone but the Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) was choppy after continued inaction by the PBoC resulted to a CNY 30bln liquidity drain, while participants also digested CPI and PPI figures which either printed inline or firmer than expected. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with demand weighed by the overall positive risk appetite and after the 5yr auction failed to support prices despite showing stronger interest with both b/c and accepted prices firmer than prior.

content:

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly higher on the momentum from Wall St where the DJIA notched its best performance in a month

    The head of the Conservative 1922 Committee indicated that he did not receive the 48 letters required for a leadership challenge

    Looking ahead, highlights include Norwegian CPI, UK monthly GDP, output, trade, German ZEW, APIs, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger

    ASIA

    Asian equity markets traded mostly higher on the momentum from Wall St where the DJIA notched its best performance in a month, and financials outperformed on optimism heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) initially took impetus from US and both opened higher although the Australia index later pared gains amid losses in its largest weighted financials sector, while Tokyo stocks remained firm on a weaker currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) conformed to the overall positive tone but the Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) was choppy after continued inaction by the PBoC resulted to a CNY 30bln liquidity drain, while participants also digested CPI and PPI figures which either printed inline or firmer than expected. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with demand weighed by the overall positive risk appetite and after the 5yr auction failed to support prices despite showing stronger interest with both b/c and accepted prices firmer than prior.

    PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 30bln. (Newswires)
    PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6259 (Prev. 6.6393)

    Chinese CPI (Jun) Y/Y 1.90% vs. Exp. 1.90% (Prev. 1.80%). (Newswires)
    Chinese PPI (Jun) Y/Y 4.70% vs. Exp. 4.50% (Prev. 4.10%)

    China Mofcom announced measures to mitigate impact of trade dispute with US, in which new tax income from countermeasures against US will mainly be utilized to ease impact to companies and workers. (Newswires)
     

    UK/EU

    There were some initial rumours that suggested pro-Brexit lawmakers have the necessary 48 'letters' to force a confidence vote on UK PM May. However, the head of the Conservative 1922 Committee indicated that he did not receive the 48 letters required for a leadership challenge, while there were comments from UK Conservative Party chairman Lewis and Eurosceptic lawmaker Rees-Mogg that they didn’t expect a confidence vote against PM May. (Newswires)

    UK PM May spokesperson stated that there is no question of revisiting the Brexit position agreed by the Cabinet on Friday, while the UK named Jeremy Hunt as the new Foreign Secretary to replace Boris Johnson following his resignation. (Newswires)


    UK BRC Retail Sales YY (Jun) 1.10% (Prev. 2.80%). (Newswires)
    UK Barclaycard Consumer Spending (Jun) 5.1% Y/Y (Prev. 5.1%)

    FX

    FX markets were mostly uneventful although the DXY edged mild gains and held above the 94.00 level, which ensured its major counterparts were contained in which EUR/USD oscillated around the 1.1750 level and GBP/USD took a breather from the prior tumultuous day triggered by cabinet resignations and threat of a no-confidence vote against UK PM May. The slightly firmer greenback and increased risk appetite helped USD/JPY just reclaim the 111.00 handle, while antipodeans were also mildly supported following the Chinese inflation figures and as CNH extended its gains with USD/CNH briefly testing 6.6000 to the downside. Elsewhere, TRY weakened after President Erdogan announced his new cabinet in which he appointed his son-in-law Berat Albayrak for the newly created Treasury and Finance Minister role which will replace the roles held by Deputy PM Simsek and Finance Minister Agbal who were both viewed as market friendly and were also seen as key advocates for higher rates.


    COMMODITIES

    Commodities saw mild upside overnight in which WTI gained a firmer footing on the USD 74.00/bbl level where it consolidated for most the session and with focus turning to today’s API inventory report and on any potential impact from oil drillers striking in Norway. Elsewhere, gold was rangebound with price action relatively calm in comparison to the prior day’s USD-driven swings, while copper is also marginally higher alongside the overall tone in the complex but has pared some of its gains as risk appetite in mainland gradually waned.

    UAE Energy Minister and OPEC President Al-Mazrouei said he doesn't foresee a need for an extraordinary meeting before December and that OPEC focus is on supply and demand balance, not targeting price. Furthermore, Al- Mazrouei had earlier commented that time is needed for extra supply to come into the market, that OPEC has enough capacity to offset output shortfalls and that OPEC doesn't want to overdo efforts to boost supply. (Newswires)

    Norway oil drillers are said to strike following failure of wage mediation discussions. (Newswires)
     

    US

    Treasury yields rose across the curve ahead of this week’s supply, with traders citing an easing of concerns regarding trade wars, as well as a ‘Goldilocks’ labour market report on Friday; rallying stock futures and a slightly higher yuan also were contributing. The long-end led the sell-off, with 10yr yields rising by c.3bps (seeing 2s10s rise a touch, taking it to just under 30bps), resulting in a modestly steeper curve. US 10YR T-notes futures (u8) settled 7 ticks lower at 120-04.

    San Francisco Fed economic letter noted economic upside from tax cuts may not meet analysts' overly optimistic expectations. (Newswires)

    US President Trump nominated judge Brett Kavanaugh for US Supreme Court Justice. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mostly higher on momentum from US where DJIA notched its best performance in a month, while region also digests Chinese inflation data
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly higher on the momentum from Wall St where the DJIA notched its best performance in a month, and financials outperformed on optimism heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) initially took impetus from US and both opened higher although the Australia index later pared gains amid losses in its largest weighted financials sector, while Tokyo stocks remained firm on a weaker currency with Yahoo Japan shares surging on reports of a share repurchase and with Softbank adding to its stake in the Co. for USD 2bln. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) conforms to the overall positive tone and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) is choppy after continued inaction by the PBoC which resulted to a CNY 30bln liquidity drain. However, there were reports that a PBoC adviser sees room for a further liquidity injection, while participants also get to digest CPI and PPI figures which either printed inline or firmer than expected.

FX markets are relatively uneventful with the DXY flat and holding above the 94.00 level which also kept trade in its major counterparts quiet, with EUR/USD oscillating around the 1.1750 level and GBP/USD taking a breather from the prior tumultuous day triggered by cabinet resignations and threat of a no-confidence vote against UK PM May. The slightly firmer greenback and increased risk appetite helped USD/JPY just about reclaim the 111.00 handle, while antipodeans are also mildly supported following the Chinese inflation figures and as CNH extends its gains with USD/CNH briefly testing 6.6000 to the downside.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued with demand weighed by the overall positive risk appetite and ahead of a 5yr auction later.
